bioghist.p: The Liberation News Service, an alternative news agency, began in 1967 as The New Media Project staffed by a cooperative of a dozen political activists in Washington, D.C. In 1968 a schism within the group resulted in the core staff moving operations to New York, led by founders Raymond Mungo and Allen Bloom. The organization originally published a packet of news information twice weekly which was sent to subscribers throughout the United States and world up until the organization's demise in 1980. The goal of the organization was to provide an alternative to the mainstream news services, UPI and AP, by documenting social and political change and activism.

scopecontent.p: This archives of a 1960s-1970s alternative news organization includes corporate bylaws and financial records, correspondence, press releases, audio tapes, photographs, pamphlets, news articles, microfilm, mailing lists, and clippings. This collection documents a wide range of subjects of interest to the cooperative media group such a Third World politics and the American social and poltical protest movement associated with issues such as civil rights, energy policy, public health, sexism, senior citizens, the Vietnam War, women's rights, racism, prisoners' rights, peace and nuclear energy. Collection correspondence documents an ongoing investigation of the organization by the F.B.I., the Department of Justice, and the Internal Revenue Service. The collection also contains extensive documentation of the organization's revenues, expenditures, and fundraising activities. Some of these corporate records for the period 1976-1980 are missing. There are extensive files on the subjects of interest and articles submitted by correspondents around the world, particularly from the emerging socialist movements in Latin America and Africa. The extensive collection of audio tapes are from two alternative news radio programs, The Rest of the News and Radio Free People, emanating from Cornell University. There is a small amount of administrative documentation for the Rest of the News and Radio Free People, including catalogs of programs, mailing lists, and fundraising information. The collection contains numerous examples of the news packets distributed to over 500 subscribers nationwide including stories, photographs, and graphics. The primary correspondents are Liberation News Service staffers; Laura Miller, Raymond Mungo, Sandy Shea, and Allen Young. The first several years of the organization archives can be found in the Marshall Bloom Collection at Amherst University.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
